awd_titl_txt: Built-In Test Mechanisms and Embedded Cores
awd_abstract_narration:
9815229

This project is a cooperative between the University of
 Arizona (Tragoudas) and Southern illinois University at
 Carbondale (Kagaris).
This project is exploring a framework for designing easily  testable cores. The method is based on the ability to  identify disjoint components in the core, called CCs (core  components),for which no implementation details are  released. Netlist information is provided for the remaining  portion of the core.  The CCs must guarantee that the  predesigned intellectual property of the core is protected  and that the testing process is simplified. Functional  faults are detected by initially testing each CC in  isolation using either Built-In Self-Testing (BIST) or scan  techniques. Subsequently, the remaining portion of the core  is tested using scan techniques while bypassing the CCs.  Path delay faults may require functional level testing for  the selected CCs. Problems being investigated are: (1)  Determining the number, sizes, locations of the CCs, and the  type of Built-In Test mechanism within each CC. (2)  Developing BIST schemes and DFT methodologies that assist in  generating the CCs within the core.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations
